qas.question: Who was thought to be influenced by continental Anabaptists?
Early seventeenth-century Baptists were thought to be influenced by who?
General Baptists shared similarities with who?

answers.text: A.C. Underwood and William R. Estep. Gourley

qas.question: What were the Dutch Waterlander Mennonites?
Who was thought to be controlled by continental Anabaptists?
Early sixteenth-century Baptists were thought to be influenced by who?
Who did the Dutch Waterlander Mennonites avoid?

context: A minority view is that <a0_0><b5_0>early seventeenth-century Baptists<b5_0/><a0_0/> were influenced by (but not directly connected to) <a1_0><b6_0>continental Anabaptists<b6_0/><a1_0/>. According to this view, the General Baptists shared similarities with <a2_0><b7_0>Dutch Waterlander Mennonites<b7_0/><a2_0/> (<a4_0>one of many <b8_0>Anabaptist groups<b8_0/><a4_0/>) including believer's baptism only, religious liberty, separation of church and state, and Arminian views of salvation, predestination and original sin. Representative writers including <a3_0>A.C. Underwood and William R. Estep. Gourley<a3_0/> wrote that among some contemporary Baptist scholars who emphasize the faith of the community over soul liberty, the <b9_0>Anabaptist influence theory<b9_0/> is making a comeback.
